H0.text: Increasing the pressure inside the wings is how a butterfly expands its crumpled wings after emerging from the chrysalis by hanging upside down and pumping fluid into the wing veins.

H1.text: Decreasing the density of the wings is how fluid pumped into the veins of a butterflyâ€™s crumpled wings after emergence from its chrysalis expands them while the butterfly hangs upside down.

H2.text: Increasing the temperature inside the wings is the process that most likely expands the wings of a butterfly that hangs upside down after emerging from its chrysalis, as fluid is pumped into the veins of its wings.

H3.text: Decreasing the mass of the wings is the mechanism that most likely expands the wings by pumping fluid into the veins when a butterfly hangs upside down after emerging from its chrysalis.

A4.text: the adult butterfly emerges from the chrysalis and expands its wings by pumping haemolymph into the wing veins.
